meta_data.title: BONUS EPISODE (with Daylan Woodall): How Do You Know Which Parts of the Bible You're Supposed to Do?
meta_data.episode_num: BONUS EPISODE (with Daylan Woodall): How Do You Know Which Parts of the Bible You're Supposed to D
meta_data.subtitle: Daylan has a book coming out! Here's the link!  Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!   Music written and performed by .

transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, I'm Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible Hour podcast and I'm joined by my good friend, Daelyn Woodall. Daelyn will say hello. Hey, Matt, how's it going? Things are great, buddy. Okay. You were the pastor at first missionary Baptist Church of Decatur, Alabama, a place that I've had a chance to hang out. What else do people need to know about you? I'm a pastor. I'm a burgeoning broadcaster. I enjoy reading, reading the Bible and consider myself to be a student of the Bible. Uh, I'm a husband. I'm a father and really enjoy having these kinds of conversations. And you have excellent taste and friends. I think that's one of your real strong suits. Well, another one of my strong suits is finding friends that are so humble. So that's the, that's the art of the backdoor self compliment time. I'm really proud of it. Uh, no, you've, you've hung out with us before on, on the podcast we do with Destin, no dumb questions. And you've been on the 10 minute Bible hour video side. We did a video down at your church about, uh, Baptist churches and specifically the, the uniqueness of a Baptist church in the south. And I, I just, I love your style, man. And I know you are working on some stuff from the epistles, the letters that make up the latter part of the New Testament. I'm working on stuff in the gospels right now. And I'm getting to a chunk here in Matthew where Jesus is harkening back to some things he said in the sermon on the Mount about obeying God and loving God at the level of the heart, not just at the level of the external actions, but it's all coming up in the midst of a controversy with the religious leaders and it's intimidating. It's, it's heavy weight stuff whenever Jesus starts to engage in this language about doing the stuff that God wants you to do and not doing the stuff that God doesn't want you to do. And I think if we are to be fair and, and thoughtful toward people who are on the front end of faith or the front end of their time with the Bible, I think it's fair to acknowledge that the Bible can be intimidating and it can be difficult to know what phrases in the Bible are things that anybody who follows Jesus for all of time is expected to do or not do. And what phrases aren't really giving you anything that you're supposed to do or not do. It can be hard for anybody, but especially it can be intimidating on the front end of faith to figure out how to tell which is which and what's going on in the text. So what I wanted to pick your brain about is how do you in the process of studying the Bible, how do you tell the difference between a part of the Bible that is telling you, Daelin, a Christian that you ought to do a thing or not do a thing? How do you tell that apart from something in the Bible that isn't really telling you anything to do or not do? Yeah, I think it's important that we approach scripture with the understanding that the Bible is a big book and there are a lot of different kinds of scripture. There's historical portions. There's portions about poetry. There are conversations. There's narrative history. So we have to approach it with an understanding that it's nuanced. And then another thing we have to understand about scripture is that there are portions of it within a single book that are more descriptive and there are portions in a single book that are more normative. There are portions in a book that describe to us what was happening at a specific chronological point in time. And then there are portions in scripture that inform us how we ought to live and how we ought to be as Christians individually and collectively. And one of the ways I've understood being able to tell the difference is looking at the language. If the passage is describing a historical event, we're going to see historical kinds of language. And it came to pass, for instance, as a common term where we see a story moving from one narrative piece to another narrative piece. And then when we hear Christ or when we read in the epistles and hear the Apostle Paul, for instance, exhorting or informing or encouraging the Christians, we see verbs that are a lot more direct. Do this. Don't do this. Let this mind that is in Christ begin you. That's direct when Jesus is talking to the disciples and he's critiquing them, not to be like the Pharisees. We have embodied in that example the issue with the Pharisees behavior and that Jesus has a rebuke or an admonishment toward the disciples to avoid that kind of behavior when he's talking to them about prayer. You know, he gives them the example in the parable of a man who is self-satisfied and self-sufficient and he prays a certain kind of way. And then another man comes in and he's humble before God and he prays another kind of way. And in that, there's, there's an application to the spirit and the approach that we ought to take to prayer. Let's brainstorm real quick. Just back and forth some phrases that you come across that for you are cues that you point out to your congregation or that you take for yourself that as you're reading along, you come across this phrase, it tells you, ah, the next thing is something that is kind of a universal instruction from God toward Christians. What, what turns of phrases can you think of that do that? And I got some in mind too. Yeah. Therefore is a really good one for me. Oh, yeah. So, okay. You get the first part of an argument if this, this, this or this, this and this are true. Therefore, and then the next thing will usually be, this is what makes sense for you. Yeah, that may, that's a good one. Um, a new command I give to you or this command I give to you, any kind of language like that where we warm up by literally saying this is a command. That's, that's pretty smoking gun. Yeah. I think, I think you're right about that. I think that gives us a sense of application, direct application. Paul is really good about saying for this reason when he's talking about history, using history as a direct example to illuminate a certain kind of instruction that he's giving to us to a specific congregation at that point. He's giving them a broader historical context for why something happens and what that has to do with us and what that has to do with his current audience in the present. Yeah. Well, what about B? It seems like when Jesus uses that language in particular, like, uh, be shrewd as serpent and innocent as doves, it seems like he's giving a command of essence. It seems like B might be a good cue. Absolutely. Definitely be and be not. You know, yeah, yeah, yeah. Both of those. Yeah. Both of those. Absolutely. I think you're right about that for sure. So if I'm hearing you right, you're saying that they're going to be, and I use this phrase all the time. I'm sure there's a better one, but they're going to be smoking gun examples that start maybe with even words like you and I are just talking about where it's like, okay, look, this is clearly intended for everybody for all time, but I bet there are some exceptions to that too, where you might find one of those words on the front end of maybe Paul writing to a church about a specific problem or issue that is going on there. You and I, we sat in your church and we talked about the historical positions, the different people held regarding the issue of slavery and how to read the parts of the Bible that deal with that. Right. And it looks like there are some parts of the Bible that are like, Hey, this is how a slave should respond to a master. Hey, this is how a master should treat a slave. Right. So when we get to something like that, does it work the other way where we can extrapolate that out and be like the Bible affirms slavery? Or can we only look at that at the narrow level of what's going on? Is, you know, is that kind of thing a universal command? Yeah, I think that's a really thoughtful question. I think we have to be careful when we read scripture of what our objective is. If our objective is to justify ourselves, justify our own beliefs and behaviors, preconceived notions and convictions, I think we're always going to around at a reading of scripture that misses the center because of the purpose of scripture, it is not to affirm us, but rather to transform us into the image of Christ. So I think we have to keep that in mind. And I think we have a tremendous amount of temptation in our reading of scripture to, to want to look at it and use it to apply and affirm some of our already pre-existing notions rather than causing us to evaluate and causing us to change what our pre-existing notions are. So I think we have to keep our eye on what the function of scripture really is. And when we find ourselves getting too comfortable, when we find ourselves coming away from scripture, feeling self-satisfied, then I think that's a, that's kind of a cue or a key that maybe we are approaching it the wrong way. It's challenging and it should be challenging. Yeah. And that's what I hear you saying. It sounds like as much as it's fun to brainstorm a few keywords and that might be kind of helpful. What I'm hearing you say is that this just requires some thought and some energy and some effort that you have to read it in great big chunks to understand what is actually being said and to be able to parse out what is a command for all people for all time or a principle that applies to all people for all time versus something descriptive about a unique moment in time. It's just hard. Is that a fair statement? Yeah, absolutely. It's hard and it takes work and it takes contemplation. It's not immediate gratification. It takes a lot of energy and a lot of effort, but it's incredibly rewarding and valuable when we give it the energy and the effort and the focus and the contemplation that it deserves. So you sound pretty optimistic. You sound like it's knowable. Yeah. It's definitely knowable. It's, you know, we have a sense that great works of art and great feats take time and dedication and commitment and exercising the discipline necessary to read scripture and become like Christ is a discipline. It's a lifetime discipline that takes time and takes focus, but it's incredibly rewarding along the way when we find ourselves growing and becoming more like Christ and responding to the issues and the challenges of our day in a way that's more consistent with his character. It took time to paint the sisting ceiling. It took time to sculpt David. It took time for the artist and the architect to give us the wonders of the ancient world and it takes time to achieve anything worthwhile and reading scripture and becoming more like Christ is the most worthwhile thing any of us could ever do. Yeah. If I'm new to this whole thing and I'm listening to this conversation, there's a part of me that's like, I don't want to do all that work. It's intimidating. It's a big book. And I'm really empathetic to that position, but I'm also really appreciative of your take on it, which is it's rewarding. It's a worthwhile investment to sort through these things. Right. And I appreciate that you keep bringing the conversation back around to the idea that ultimately figuring out what passages are the things you are supposed to do. Isn't really the point of the Bible. If it was the point of the Bible, every page would just be a numbered list of the next things you ought to do and the things you ought not to do. Right. But the very way the Bible is arranged points us back to the reality that I mean, the primary function to use your terminology of the Bible is the revelation of God. It's to understand the truth of that being, which is greater than the natural world. And to get toward answers that are rooted in that truth that are bigger than being a behavior, but on some levels will ultimately involve behavior. Absolutely. And I think that bigger perspective you're describing is clarifying. Well, that's encouraging to hear. I think about, you know, the example of a marathon runner who has people along the path with these small little cups of water. It's not all the water they need to finish the race, but it's enough to refresh them and to encourage them and to remind them that there'll be more water and more refreshment and more encouragement and more cheers and more enthusiasm along the way. We read scripture and along the way we're refreshed along the way we're encouraged along the way. We're admonished, but we're reminded that there's a more rewarding journey and it's going to take time and it's going to take effort and it's going to take focus, but we can get there. I like that take and you're getting the last word because that's well said. Daelin, if people want to look you up or find your stuff on the internet, where do they find you? First, mb.org. You got sermons and stuff on there? Yeah, we have sermons. We have a couple of podcasts. We're working on some more projects. We're going to be uploading soon. So yeah, that's, that's where we are. That's where we can find us. My email is up there. If anybody wants to email me and start a conversation. It's up there as well. I appreciate you. I like your style, my friend. This has been a great time, Matt. Thanks so much for having me. You bet. All right. Hey, thanks for hanging out with me and Daelin. We will pick it up with more Matthew stuff on Monday. I'm Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.

Right.
And it looks like there are some parts of the Bible that are like, Hey, this is how
a slave should respond to a master.
Hey, this is how a master should treat a slave.
Right.

Is, you know, is that kind of thing a universal command?
Yeah, I think that's a really thoughtful question.
I think we have to be careful when we read scripture of what our objective is.

Yeah.
And that's what I hear you saying.
It sounds like as much as it's fun to brainstorm a few keywords and that might

What I'm hearing you say is that this just requires some thought and some

what is actually being said and to be able to parse out what is a command for

versus something descriptive about a unique moment in time.
It's just hard.
Is that a fair statement?
Yeah, absolutely.
It's hard and it takes work and it takes contemplation.
It's not immediate gratification.
It takes a lot of energy and a lot of effort, but it's incredibly rewarding
and valuable when we give it the energy and the effort and the focus and the
contemplation that it deserves.
So you sound pretty optimistic.
You sound like it's knowable.
Yeah.
It's definitely knowable.
It's, you know, we have a sense that great works of art and great feats take
time and dedication and commitment and exercising the discipline necessary to
read scripture and become like Christ is a discipline.
It's a lifetime discipline that takes time and takes focus, but it's
incredibly rewarding along the way when we find ourselves growing and becoming
more like Christ and responding to the issues and the challenges of our day in a
way that's more consistent with his character.
It took time to paint the sisting ceiling.
It took time to sculpt David.
It took time for the artist and the architect to give us the wonders of the
ancient world and it takes time to achieve anything worthwhile and reading scripture
and becoming more like Christ is the most worthwhile thing any of us could ever do.
Yeah.
If I'm new to this whole thing and I'm listening to this conversation,
there's a part of me that's like, I don't want to do all that work.
It's intimidating.
It's a big book.
And I'm really empathetic to that position, but I'm also really appreciative of your
take on it, which is it's rewarding.
It's a worthwhile investment to sort through these things.
Right.

that ultimately figuring out what passages are the things you are supposed to do.
Isn't really the point of the Bible.
If it was the point of the Bible, every page would just be a numbered list of the

Right.

the primary function to use your terminology of the Bible is the revelation of God.
It's to understand the truth of that being, which is greater than the natural world.

a behavior, but on some levels will ultimately involve behavior.
Absolutely.
And I think that bigger perspective you're describing is clarifying.

I think about, you know, the example of a marathon runner who has people along the

It's not all the water they need to finish the race, but it's enough to refresh

We read scripture and along the way we're refreshed along the way we're
encouraged along the way.
We're admonished, but we're reminded that there's a more rewarding journey and it's

we can get there.
I like that take and you're getting the last word because that's well said.
Daelin, if people want to look you up or find your stuff on the internet, where
do they find you?
First, mb.org.
You got sermons and stuff on there?
Yeah, we have sermons.
We have a couple of podcasts.
We're working on some more projects.
We're going to be uploading soon.
So yeah, that's, that's where we are.
That's where we can find us.
My email is up there.
If anybody wants to email me and start a conversation.
It's up there as well.
I appreciate you.
I like your style, my friend.
This has been a great time, Matt.
Thanks so much for having me.
You bet.
All right.
Hey, thanks for hanging out with me and Daelin.
We will pick it up with more Matthew stuff on Monday.
I'm Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast.
Let's do this again soon.
